title: Product Handling Procedures
description: Requirements for safe product handling during harvest including dropped product protocols, ground contact prevention, product protection from contamination, and proper handling practices

requirements.question: Are workers trained to handle product in a manner that prevents physical damage and contamination?
Are procedures in place to minimize the time between harvest and cooling or processing?
Is product protected from direct contact with soil during harvest operations?
requirements.automaticFailureReason: Product contact with soil presents direct microbial contamination risk from pathogens in soil.

requirements.question: Are procedures in place to segregate damaged or suspect product from sound product?
Are harvest containers filled to appropriate levels to prevent product damage and contamination?
Is product protected from contamination during transport from field to packing or storage areas?

mandatoryStatements: Workers must be trained to handle product gently to prevent bruising, cutting, or other physical damage that could provide entry points for pathogens.
Procedures must minimize the time between harvest and cooling or processing to maintain product quality and reduce microbial growth.
Product must be protected from direct contact with soil throughout harvest operations to prevent contamination with soil-borne pathogens.
Damaged, dropped, or suspect product must be segregated from sound product to prevent cross-contamination.
Product must be protected from environmental contamination during transport from field to packing or storage facilities.
capaInject: Develop detailed product handling procedures specific to each crop type including acceptable practices and prohibited actions.
Implement a quality control program with visual inspections during harvest to identify and segregate damaged or contaminated product.
Establish maximum time limits from harvest to cooling for different product types and monitor compliance through timestamped records.
Create protocols for protecting product from soil contact including proper container use, careful handling, and immediate removal if dropped.
Design transport procedures that minimize exposure time, prevent physical damage, and protect product from dust, debris, and environmental contamination.
traceabilityInject: Maintain harvest time records showing start time, completion time, and time to cooling for each lot or field section.
Document any product segregation including reason (damage, drop, contamination), quantity, location, and disposition.
Keep records of product quality inspections during harvest including inspector, time, observations, and corrective actions.
Track transport times and conditions from field to facility including vehicle/trailer ID, departure time, arrival time, and temperature if applicable.
Log any deviations from standard handling procedures including description, impact assessment, and corrective actions taken.
micro_inject: Emphasize that physical damage to product (cuts, bruises, breaks) creates entry points for pathogens and increases risk of microbial growth.
Ensure workers understand that soil contains high levels of bacteria including E. coli, Salmonella, and Listeria that can contaminate product surfaces.
Implement protocols to minimize warm holding times which allow rapid multiplication of any bacteria present on product surfaces.
Verify that segregation of damaged product prevents cross-contamination through direct contact or shared containers and equipment.
Monitor that transport conditions do not create opportunities for microbial growth through extended warm temperatures or moisture accumulation.
